docs.text: Fluids # Buoyancy # Buoyant Force # F_B = \rho_fV_{disp}g F_B = \rho_fV_{disp}g Buoyancy depends on density of the fluid and the displacing volume of the object. When an object is floating, F_B F_B is equal to the force of gravity. Flow # AP fluids are generally assumed to be incompressible and have no turbulence/friction, so flow rate/continuity is useful. Flow Rate # Q = \frac{V}{\Delta t}\\ Q = \frac{lA}{\Delta t}\\ Q = vA Q = \frac{V}{\Delta t}\\ Q = \frac{lA}{\Delta t}\\ Q = vA Flow Continuity Equation # Q_1 = v_1a_1 = v_2a_2 = Q_2 Q_1 = v_1a_1 = v_2a_2 = Q_2 Bernoulli's Equation # P_1 - P_2 = \frac{1}{2} \rho \left(v_2^2 - v_1^2\right) + \rho g\left(y_2 - y_1\right) P_1 - P_2 = \frac{1}{2} \rho \left(v_2^2 - v_1^2\right) + \rho g\left(y_2 - y_1\right) Useful conservation of energy form # P_1 + \rho gy_1 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_1^2 = P_2 + \rho gy_2 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_2^2 P_1 + \rho gy_1 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_1^2 = P_2 + \rho gy_2 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_2^2
docs.title: Fluids

docs.title: Bernoulli's Equation

docs.text: P_1 + \rho gy_1 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_1^2 = P_2 + \rho gy_2 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_2^2 P_1 + \rho gy_1 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_1^2 = P_2 + \rho gy_2 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_2^2
docs.title: Useful conservation of energy form

docs.text: Thermodynamics # First Law of Thermodynamics # \Delta U = Q + W \Delta U = Q + W Heat/Energy Equations # The big daddy of thermo # U = \frac{1}{2}mv_{rms}^2 = \frac{3}{2}Nk_BT = \frac{3}{2}nRT = \frac{3}{2}PV U = \frac{1}{2}mv_{rms}^2 = \frac{3}{2}Nk_BT = \frac{3}{2}nRT = \frac{3}{2}PV This equation is derived from the kinetic energy of a single molecule and the ideal gas law. Specific heat # Q = mc\Delta T Q = mc\Delta T Temperature to raise mass m m of substance with specific heat c c , \Delta T \Delta T degrees. If there is a phase change, then you need to calculate the energy for that with the latent heat equation. Latent heat # Q_F = mL_F \\ Q_V = mL_V Q_F = mL_F \\ Q_V = mL_V Use latent heat equations to calculate energy required for phase changes (fusion or vaporization). Efficiency # e = \frac{Q_H - Q_C}{Q_H} = \frac{W}{Q_H} e = \frac{Q_H - Q_C}{Q_H} = \frac{W}{Q_H} Ideal efficiency (Carnot Engine) # e_c = \frac{T_H - T_C}{T_H} = 1 - \frac{T_C}{T_H} e_c = \frac{T_H - T_C}{T_H} = 1 - \frac{T_C}{T_H} For a Carnot engine, the efficiency can be determined by the temperatures of the heat reservoirs because of entropy or something. Heat transfer rate (conduction) # \frac{Q}{\Delta t} = \frac{kA\Delta T}{L} \frac{Q}{\Delta t} = \frac{kA\Delta T}{L} "It's just an equation"
docs.title: Thermodynamics
